stem: For each assessment finding, click to indicate if the finding is consistent with right-sided heart failure, left-sided heart failure, or neither.

itemContext.sbar: John Smith is a 68-year-old male admitted with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease.

rationale.correct: Crackles in the lungs, S3 heart sound, and pulmonary congestion are indicative of left-sided heart failure due to fluid backing up into the lungs. Jugular venous distention and lower extremity edema are indicative of right-sided heart failure due to systemic fluid overload.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the pathophysiology of right-sided and left-sided heart failure.
clinicalPearls: Left-sided heart failure primarily affects the lungs, while right-sided heart failure primarily affects the systemic circulation.
BNP is a marker for heart failure, and elevated levels support the diagnosis.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may confuse the symptoms of right-sided and left-sided heart failure. Focus on the primary areas affected by each type of failure.
rationale.mnemonic: L for Lungs (Left-sided heart failure), R for Rest of the body (Right-sided heart failure)
